segments.text: War was a war of small groups, basically, out by themselves.
There'd be a patrol, maybe an army patrol of anywhere from six to twelve people would go out.
And they'd be out, you know, maybe four or five miles from anybody else.
And a lot of times a guy got hit, he got left, you know, because there just wasn't any way to get him back.
The other guys were, you know, they were under attack and having to fight their way out.
And if somebody got hit and he dropped, they most of the time couldn't even get to him, you know, to see what was going on.
So it was assumed he was dead and he was left.
Some of the fighting was in the camps, particularly among the ranger camps that had come in at night.
But they were pretty well bunkered, and it was just kind of a...
It wasn't a whole lot of shooting going on in the daytime in a lot of areas in Vietnam.
It was a nighttime operation.
Do you have a lot of hypochondriacs looking for a medical way out of war?
Didn't have a lot, but we had some.
Some?
We didn't call them hypochondriacs.
They were malingering.
Malingering?
That's a conscious effort to try and get out of something,
as opposed to somebody who may have some psychosomatic symptoms.
We had both kinds.
We had some psychosomatic symptoms of people who just subconsciously said, you know, I've got to get out of here, so they got sick.
And, you know, all the physical signs, everything else.
They were, that was a psychosomatic symptom that they were having.

uh but we had some who would come in think we've had some shoot themselves but they're very much of a minority we even had them come in and deliberately fail their golden clothes you know their urine check for drugs guys that probably never took a drug in their life would take some and then run quickly
because those guys got sent home, even though they may wind up with a dishonorable or a general discharge.
It was worth it to them to get out of Vietnam.
How did the American military medical system compare to that of South Vietnam?
Well, South Vietnam was grossly inferior.
Their system
And much of their equipment and so forth was American.
They didn't have very many doctors.
The doctors that they had, some of them were very good.
Some of them were not well-trained at all.
Their hospitals, they had a 1,000-bed hospital in downtown Da Nang.
They were sleeping sometimes three to a bed.
Americans didn't take near the number of casualties that the Vietnamese had.
And they couldn't be shipped off somewhere.
They had to stay in country, and they got up just as soon as they could, and they sent them back to the war.
When I was talking to Dr. Walker, he mentioned the MedCap system, but he didn't.
Can you tell me a little bit about that?
Yeah.
Basically, there was a two-tiered structure there.
Besides the military medicine business, they also had what they called a cord, which is a state department, a function of the state department, not of the department of military.
These people were there to advise and to set up public health programs, industrial medicine programs, set up little clinics and things in the various small communities.
In addition, they would frequently ask us to provide manpower to go out to little villages and stuff that hadn't seen a doctor for years and go out there and examine and treat what we could.
So once a week, we would take, we'd go out to some of the little refugee areas around Da Nang and have a clinic.
And we saw everything from scrofula, TB, to schistosomiasis, you know, every disease you can imagine over there, typhoid.
many, many things, and we would just take a long supply of drugs and give them enough that we thought would treat that, that would treat a lot of injuries, wounds, infections, and this sort of thing.
But we had that, and we had a dentist would go along, and he would pull teeth and try and improve the dental care, which generally was very poor.
But this was something that was ongoing at every military medical facility.
We always spent some time doing that sort of thing.
Do you think of any problems, looking back, with the medical system in Vietnam?
Oh, gosh.
Do you think it should change?
The biggest problem?
was not so much with the system, although the system is like any system.
It's got its bureaucracies, and sometimes it is just hell-getting things that you need.
You've got to be able to learn to work with the system and plan ahead and keep yourself stockpiled.
And sometimes you'd run out of stuff and you'd have to make a whole bunch of phone calls, you know.
It was a major pain in the ass sometimes to get some things, which you could almost always get.
I can't think of any time we really suffered when we were out of something.
The system was bureaucratically overloaded.
There were a lot more administrators sometimes, I think, than there were people out doing the job.
That was one thing that's true of every big business.
You can go down to Hillcrest and see the same thing.
We've got too many people administrating, not enough people doing the work.
Bureaucracy is one problem, but it wasn't a major, and it was a nuisance, but it wasn't a major problem.
The biggest real problem we had over there was the lack of support from him.

You know, the average GI heard he got letters from his girlfriend or from his wife or from his mother and father, and he read the newspapers and he saw the TV and things like that, and he got pretty discouraged.
You know, here he's over there getting his butt shot at, and people burning the flag in Washington, D.C., and that sort of thing.
There just wasn't any support, and so it's kind of a, you know, so what type attitude was kind of easy to prevail.
And, you know, seeing your friends, guys that you were buddying up with getting killed and
and so forth while all this was going on was really a very disheartening process.

And I think that's one of the things that everybody who went to Vietnam carries with them a little bit, is a real resentment at being shoved off there to do and die without family or anything for a year or two years or however long it happened to be.
people bad-mouthing Jane Fonda.
They burned Jane Fonda in effigy at the officer's club one night when she was visiting in North Vietnam.

And our esteemed fourth estate, we had a lot of reporters and stuff around there, and most of the time they were in the bar getting drunk, and they'd sit down and type out some story that was so far removed from the truth.
We had good ones, too.
I'm not saying they were all like that.
We had some real losers over there.
They greatly destroyed my respect for the news media.
I know that a lot of the vets were ill received when they came back home.
How was that for you?
I think there are a couple of little incidents that happened to, you know, people being kind of rude.
Nothing major that I can think of.
No problem finding a job or anything?
No.
I went back.
Of course, I was still on active duty and went back to that.
a cushy job.
The biggest problem I had was going from something where things were life and death and you got things done to a real Mickey Mouse bureaucratic, super bureaucratic oriented society.
It took me a couple of years again not to get pissed off every time somebody asked me to fill out something in triplicate.
I'm going to wrap this up.
Find out statements from people who implemented the war, administrators, and people back here get their opinions on why we were there and what went on and all.
From you, a doctor's point of view, why was America in Vietnam?
Well,

i don't know that i can give you one as a doctor's point of view because it's impossible to have a doctor's point of view on that i met a lot of people over there and several missionary type fellas and women i remember i met one a lady who ran an orphanage that we kind of took care of and
She and her husband had been in Vietnam for 20 years and been taken care of.
They had this orphanage and they took care of the kids and it was up north, up toward Hue.
And one night the Viet Cong, the North Vietnamese came in, took her out, beat her up, raped her, shot her husband, and took all the male children off.
And some of the older female children were raped.
And then they just kind of left.
I met a Catholic priest who was born in Canada, a French parentage, and then moved to Hanoi.
when he was fairly young, was raised in Hanoi, which at that time was French.
And was raised there, went to seminary back in Canada, I guess, and then came back to Hanoi where he practiced.
And he, of course, when the French were fighting after the war with the French, he divided the country.
He and, uh, several other people who were in French Distraction came south.
Well, uh, he was telling us about how the, uh, Viet Cong recruited.
He said they'd take one man and go into a village, and some of these villages were only, you know, 10, 12 families.
They'd go in there and they'd call, and they'd have guns.
Nobody else had guns.
They'd call out,
and they'd take the head man and shoot him.
And they'd say, I want every one of you to follow me.
He says, if you don't, we're going to kill everybody in the village.
So all the males would go out, and they'd take these eight guys, and they'd go into a bigger village and do the same thing.
Until from that one communist, he had recruited about 150, 200 people, all of which were then
politically indoctrinated and so forth, but basically held they would have done in the threats of killing their family.
And this is how it all started.
Now, later on, you have to go back in the Vietnamese history.
The Vietnamese had been subjugated by just about everybody who moved.
In that whole part of the world, the Chinese were first.
And there's still a great deal of enmity between the Chinese, although there were a lot of Chinese, particularly in South Vietnam.
There were a lot of Chinese ancestry people there.
But the Vietnamese have no fondness for the Chinese at all, as you can see by recent events.
the Vietnamese were basically fighting a war for independence.
They wanted to be Vietnamese, they wanted their own country, and they wanted, that was it.
So later, when the, after the Communists became a little stronger, they were able to parlay this nationalistic point of view.
into some recruits who really believed that, you know, things had been really lousy under the French.
Things had been really lousy before that, and before that, and before that.
Why not give these other guys a chance?
And they taught good, and in fact they had done some good.
The life of the Vietnamese right now is
somewhat better than it has ever been before, although they've still got a long way to go.
They're still a very poor country.
A lot of good natural resources, you know, hardwood forests and a lot of fishing and stuff, but they just don't have the capital to exploit it.
So a lot of people could see this, you know, but nevertheless, it was
my contention that anything that starts out as this started out has got to be inherently evil.
And that is my reason why I feel that if there was a reason for being there, that must be it.
Now, that's not to say that I think we should have been there.
Because I think had we not blindly aided the French and had helped Ho Chi Minh

at the time when he asked for help, that we could have reverted this whole business and had, true, a communist society, as Yugoslavia was communist, as Romania and several other countries in which we had fairly good relations were communist, but we could have had a lot more stability in that area and maybe prevented some of the Cambodian and other real problems that we have now, or they have no longer in the country.
Uh, why do you think we lost?
Because we weren't committed to win.
That's all the questions I have prepared.
Is there anything that you can think of that might be helpful in my research or that you'd like to add?
No, I don't know.
We've got a lot of good information from him.
Bear in mind, I haven't thought about Vietnam for a long time, so I can't think of too much else.
It's really interesting.
I'll just tell you some anecdotal things now.
They're probably not going to be of any great interest.
I was dual-rated.
I was a physician, and I was also a pilot.
So I flew F-4 combat missions while I was over there, too.
And mostly at night, because I worked, you know, had my hands full during the day.
You know, you're either busy or bored, and, you know, I'll tell you.
Sitting in a two-by-whoops drink and scratching my idea, not the way to pass the time.
It's not my thing, so I kept kind of busy.
But anyway, I'd get up, breathe permission, get through working about 7 or 8 o'clock, go home, sleep for a couple hours, breathe permission at 1 o'clock, and fly until about 7 or 8 in the morning.
And I had some very interesting experiences.
at Da Nang, you could not land from the south coming north, because you passed over what was called Arizona territory.
And this was territory that was mostly rice fields and stuff that was controlled by the Viet Cong.
And this is where rockets came from.
And it was kind of a day-only.
Now, we could go in there during the day,
And nobody ever saw or heard of them, they say.
They were little farming villages.
But at night, you know, they owned it.
And we used to fly over there.
And, you know, the first time I flew over there at night, I looked down and I had a navigator in the back and I was sitting there flying.
I said, well, some people are shooting at us down there.
Oh, yeah, they shoot us all the time.
We come in on a GCA final.
People down there shooting at you with handguns and rifles and stuff.
And after the push,

Now, the Tet Offensive, they got down pathway, which was only about 80 miles from us, and they were down into the big peninsula across there, and they had 23-millimeter machine guns that were shooting at us, coming around to turn on GCA final landing to the south.
So it got to be very interesting.
You know, you never flew with your lights on, and if you did, you know, all of a sudden there's craters all around you.
It was really a different situation.
Okay.
All right.
And there was a lot of interesting things.
They were talking about this body count business.
And that was something that got really grossly overrated then.
You know, I'd go up on a day mission or something like that, and we'd go up with a FAC, which was usually flying either an OD-10 or an O2.

Occasionally, we'd use a FAST FAC, which was a guy in either an F-100 or an F-4, that would go fly low to the ground, find something, and zap up and shoot a smoke rocket, a phosphorus rocket, down to mark the target.
And we'd come in from up on high.
We were safe from small arms fire, come down,
drop bombs and stuff on them.
Then this guy in his fastback would zip by and say, oh, it looks like about 30.
He could no more tell what the thing was.
Even the guys in the slow movies, there's just no way, no way they could ever tell, you know, what the body count was.
They'd all come up with some magic number.
I always got the biggest kickback that way.
The body count on there was just so grossly unreliable it wouldn't do it next time.
It wasn't all that important anymore.
Well.
Yeah, there were a lot of fun things.
We took some, went down to, there was a ranger outfit that had three guys, and they were the advisors to the militia.
And it was in a little village about 25, 30 miles from Jenaim.
Right at the beginnings of this Arizona territory, I was telling you about.
The V.C.
owned it pretty much during the night.
But anyway, these Ranger guys were trying to organize these villagers into protecting themselves against the V.C.
And I got to be pretty good friends with Provost Marshall.
And in a combat situation in the Air Force, our security police
which are ordinarily the cops, so to speak, become split into two sections.
They have the cops, and then they have kind of like an infantry battalion, and they're equipped with everything up to light tanks.
They've got grenade launchers and all that stuff.
We had a fair amount of ordnance, and he was always running out and couldn't get it from the Army.
We'd load up a caravan.

I'd take my jeep, he'd take his, and we'd get one other jeep, and we'd go down and we would arm ourselves with a couple of M-16s and handguns and some M-60 grenade launchers and stuff, and we'd haul a whole bunch of ordnance down to him, and he'd give us the cook's tour of all the little villages.
If you can imagine
50 people living on a space of land not much bigger than this lot.
And in houses made of cardboard and a few pieces of wood, tin, and all this sort of thing.
These were the refugee villages.
And little kids running around without any clothes, very little to eat.
They were really heart-wrenching.
And I could see why somebody that had to live like that, you know, when the Americans in the area, they thought their government, that was all they could do for them.
I could see why they might think, well, hell, this is all we're getting.
We can do better with the other side.
There was a lot to it.
Vietnam is a beautiful country.
And a hundred years when all the scars have gone, and that place really comes in, it would be a great place to take a trip.
Great place to take a trip.
It's a huge, big forest, hardwood forest, trees 300 feet tall, and beautiful white sandy beaches, and all kinds of good fishing and things like that.
It's just all badly polluted by man.
If we could just kind of exterminate man from that whole setup and then kind of come in and repopulate it, I think we'd be all right.
Very interesting.
I can sit and listen to stories all night.
